Name: Kim Bac
Description:
Theme:
In Chinese, Kim-Bac means "the treasure seeker". A breath-taking treasure race in the narrow streets of an old Chinese town: that's the theme of this new game, fast paced, constantly renewed with an uncut suspense.

Kim-Bac is played in to phases: in the first one, "where is the treasure hidden?", all the treasure seekers try to put their hands on the chest that contains the secret of the treasure hideout.
In the second phase: "the treasure race", a single player, the Kim-Bac, knows where the treasure is hidden. All the others ally to capture him and share out the treasure.
Randomness almost never occurs in this second game phase. Alone against everyone, will the Kim-Bac be able to reach the treasure hideout?


Thème :
En chinois, Kim-Bac veut dire "le cherche trésor". Une haletante course au trésor dans les étroites ruelles d'une vieille ville chinoise : c'est le sujet de ce nouveau jeu au rythme rapide et au suspense ininterrompu, constamment renouvelé.

Kim-Bac se joue en deux parties : dans la première : "où le trésor est-il caché ?", tous les chercheurs de trésor essayent de mettre la main sur le coffre qui contient le secret de la cachette du trésor.
Dans la deuxième partie : "la course au trésor", un seul joueur, le Kim-Bac, sait à quel endroit le trésor est caché. Tous les autres s'allient entre eux pour le capturer et se partager le trésor.
Le hasard n'intervient presque pas dans cette deuxième partie du jeu. Seul contre tous, le Kim-Bac pourra-t-il parvenir jusqu'à la cachette du trésor ?

Name: Cadwallon: City of Thieves – The Inn
Description:
Before their nightly adventures begin, the gangs visit the Inn to equip themselves.
Each gang can choose any two equipment cards to use, but they’ll have to pay for them with the loot that they collect during the game!

Name: Many Monster Dice
Description:
This game developed out of a BGG dice design contest game i posted a few months ago (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/552079/my-many-monster-dice-game-competition-win-gg). My solo game rules for the pictured dice (which can be purchased at http://www.flyingbuffalo.com/) is as follows:

Many Dungeon Dice

You’ll need the many monster dice, paper to keep track of your character and draw out your dungeon, and a pen.

Roll the D20 to discover how many monsters you must encounter during your game and mark this value down. You must defeat this number of monsters to win the game without being slain yourself. Any gold and jewels you have left at the end if yours to keep.

Then, with the five numbered dice, assign one die to each 5 values - monster hit point die, and attack and defense dice.

Roll the map die, drawing out your dungeon as you go. Be as artistic as you like in this. Stairs and doors always have traps. Each door you roll will enter into a room, and there will always be a unlocked exit door in an adjacent wall. The T corridor branches off into other hallways and you may backtrack your path if you wish during exploration.

If you roll a door or a stair check first for a trap by rolling the 3 trap dice, if two faces match that trap is sprung.

Next, if you rolled a door, you enter the room. Roll the colored monster die to see what level of monster you will fight, and roll the corresponding colored monster die to see what you will fight. You always have initiative in an encounter.

To battle:

Roll your Battle Strength die and add that value to your Battle Strength for a magical weapon if you possess one. Then roll for the monster. Depending on the color and type of monster they will have different strengths and powers as summarized in the rules.

Once you have defeated a monster you may roll for treasure using the Treasure Die.

Explore the dungeon until you defeat/kill all the monsters you are required to. If you do this count yourself lucky you survived with your limbs and sanity intact. Spend your gold at the nearest wenchery or tavern.

Name: 9 Letter Word
Description:
An abstract game for two players. Played on nine wooden tiles (different colored fronts and backs) with ten wooden tokens (five per player).
Players either move their pieces or flip over tokens in an alternating order.
The aim of the game is to gather four of your pieces on one tile, or to control most of the play area (tiles show your color).

Name: Scrabble Switch-Up
Description:
Scrabble game features six interchangeable board games. You can play the classic game, or try a version with "blanks" and "blockers." You can even design your own custom game with the nine mini-boards.  Some of the boards have themes like "outer space" or "in the clouds."

Other than the classic game, here are the variations you can try with Scrabble Switch-Up

Blanks and Blockers: If you play a letter that covers a blank or block square you take the appropriate tile. A blank acts as a normal wild card with the added bonus that it doesn't count as one of your seven. A blocker is a tile you can play immediately to prevent someone else from using a specific square.

Bustin' Out:  Make words that lead you outside the walled in junkyard. This variation also uses cards - land on a guard dog and draw a card that you can use to mess up another player.

Hyper-Race: A two player game with the object of making words crossword style that lead from the space station at the top to the earth below. Land on a comet and get a free blank tile. Land on a flying saucer and draw a card similar to the guard dogs above.

Free for All: Uses a smaller 9X9 grid with the expanded rule that words can now be made diagonally with a limit of three words made per turn.

Surprise: Allows you to completely change the traditional Scrabble board by mixing up where the premium spots are located plus adds new ones such as wild and quadruple score. You have nine double sided squares that you use to make up the entire board.

Name: The Inn Game
Description:
The object of this business game is to become the wealthiest player through buying and operating hotel properties. This unique title was published by the Holiday Inn corporation... the good hotels have the Holiday Inn logo but the bad inns are called The Heartbreak Hotel!

Players move around a board similar to Monopoly by rolling dice and then use a spinner to determine if the hotel will be a good Holiday Inn or a stinker. Players can upgrade a hotel by adding recreational facilities or a convention center.

The board includes cities in the USA, Asia, and Europe. The players buy and sell hotels while paying rent on an opponent's property. The last player with any cash is declared the winner.

Includes a colorful board, tokens, spinner, rules, play money, dice, hotel logo markers, and property cards.

Name: Jolly Robbers, A Shooting Game
Description: JOLLY ROBBERS: A SHOOTING GAME from  Wilder Manufacturing ca. 1920. The game comes with illustrated pictures that can be erected to form a village with a wall. 5 Gnomes are set up on the wall and the object of the game is to shoot them off with a pop-gun. Each target hit scores points.

Name: Panama Canal Game
Description: This is a simple roll and move game which shows the commercial routes through the Canal. First to get through the canal and get back after delivering their cargo wins the game. (from the Parker Brothers Catalog for 1920)

Name: Kiel: A Naval Battle Game
Description: This game shows attacks on German forts by American, British and French vessels in World War 1. The game comes with shells for the guns and tracking lines for the shots taken by both the vessels firing at and the forts returning fire. Rolls of the dice determined hits or misses.

Name: Alien Armada
Description:
Publisher Blurb:

Alien Armada is the third book in our series of module using the Starmada game system. This includes ships from the Tholians, Neo-Tholians, Seltorians, and Orion Pirates, along with some bonus ships.There are Q-ships, base stations, monitors, and defense satellites for most empires. Rules for webs, web casters, web breakers, particle cannons. This book requires Klingon Armada to play. The Starmada Admiralty Edition Core Rules aren't required but would add more player options and opportunities.

Name: GaroBouc
Description:
From the publisher:
Fast new kids game for who like to gamble with luck and hope for the best. Be the brave hiker and sneak by the goat, so you would be pushed off the mountain hard.

Each player has two hikers in their own color and spin the spinner. Then they have a choice of move (1-3), not move at all (pass) or move the goat.
Goat makes random circles and kicked of one hiker (if it can hit it). First player to reach the mountain top is the winner.

Name: Tchin Tchin: Barmaid
Description:
Extra character card that was sold in Essen '06

Bartender used as a card "character" to play up to 9 additional players!
However, it does toast with those who drink Alcohol is often used in preparing So delicious cocktails it is in fact part as appetizers with champagne, tequila or vodka (hence the three glasses represented the illustration)! 
Apart from this, it is like everyone else so it must make the gesture to drink and pronounce the word related to the nationality of each drinker's drink which she participates.

But be careful because if general tour paid by the bartender or in-between the direct involvement (see rule of the game), then we should pretend to shake a shaker saying "Cocktail" to win!

Name: Death Cup
Description:
Death Cup is a fast-paced party game, combining the luck of dice and the precision of quarter bouncing. Pass the Shot Cup around the table, bouncing quarters into it to get ahead, but beware the Death Cup, for when it descends, one unfortunate soul may lose all of their coins. The dice determine your fate, but it is up to your dexterity to prove your worth. When the Death Cup has dispatched all but three players, the final showdown begins: a blitzing battle of attrition in both coins and sobriety until only one player is left standing.

A player will either be confronted with the Shot Cup and the Shot Dice or the Death Cup and Death Dice (if in a Death Round *speed round*). In Final Fight it is a combination of the two. The player rolls the dice and then performs an action depending on what they rolled. Generally Skulls are bad and numbers are good and dollar signs are really good. The last player in the game with Tokens is declared the winner of Death Cup

ALL HAIL THE DEATH CUP!!!

Name: Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer – Vedah, Sage of Swords Promo
Description:
This promotional card was given out to participants in the first Ascension Game Day December 4th 2010.

Cost: 7 Runes

Enlightened Hero

Reveal the top card of the center deck. Draw or defeat it.

4 Honor

In the event that playing Vedah, Sage of Swords results in the player drawing an Event from the Portal Deck, the following steps should be taken:

     Banish the Event. The Event does not enter play.
     Draw another card from the Portal Deck. If the player draws another Event, repeat Step 1.


 Errata: When Dhartha's Retreat is in play, the card "drawn" from the Portal Deck is actually considered an "acquired" card. As such, the effect provided by Dhartha's Retreat is cancelled. This marks the only instance where the term "draw" is synonymous with "acquire." A second printing of this card will address this fact.

Name: Power Grid: BGG Promo Card Set
Description:
In early 2011 BGG began to offer the Funkenschlag/Power Grid Promo Card set, featuring all previously released promo cards plus a brand new card - the Theme Park (Freizeitpark).

The Theme Park needs so much electricity, that it counts as a whole city.

The Promo Card Set includes 7 cards:

     Power Grid: Flux Generator (2008)
     Power Grid: Transformer Station (2009)
     Power Grid: Warehouse (2010, 3 cards)
     Power Grid: Theme Park (2011)
     replacement "Step 3" card

Name: Casino Dice
Description:
"The Pocket Casino"

The greatest gambling game of the century, brings Monte Carlo into your own home.

The game includes (Pocket edition): 
one cloth (in pocket Case)
two dice
100 counters 
rules.

Casino dice the latest Gambling Game of the Century is similar, to a certain extenr, to Roulette.
It is played with two Dice and the odds, payable by the Baker, ranges from "even money" to 12 to 1 according to whether single numbers, doubles, sequences, or totals are backed. 
There are 29 seperate bets on the cloth, and all odds are clearly shown.

The folding "Pocket Edition" Size 6 inches by 3 3/4 inches, opening out to 17 inches by 11 inches. Complete with two dice.

The "De Luxe" Club Outfit, on Rexine Leather Cloth, Size 50" x 24" with Dice Cup, Dice, Rules and Counters.

- summary from game box, rules and game flyer

Name: Halos' n Horns
Description: This roll and move game was designed to help teach children the positive and negative consequences to their actions. Based on their decisions in 'real-life' situations they could earn Halos be doing the morally correct thing, or earn Horns by choosing the morally incorrect thing to do in a given situation.

Name: Hey! That's My Tile!
Description:
Hey! That's My Tile! is a dice-driven tile colleting game played with Nestortiels (1 Set of Nestortiles A-type and 1 pawn per player) 
Players try to collect as many tiles as possible by moveing their pawn on a grid of 8x8 tiles. 
Each player boulds his own die with 6 tiles. They roll thier dice and move to tiles of the colour or number the die shows. Players than replace one side of their die with the tile they moved on. 
At the end of the game, it´s not only important to have a lot of tiles, but also to have tiles with different numbers and colours.

Name: Squadron Strike: Ship Book 2 – The Three Face War
Description:
The setting of the Posthuman Diaspora Goes to War! Squadron Strike allows you to build any ship from any universe; the home grown setting for Squadron Strike, introduced in the boxed set, gets an expansion with 15 more ships, plus registration benefits as the Japanese, Russians and Rhodesians slip into the posthuman conflict, where through mirroring one another, they go from war as a hobby to war as an avocation, carefully bound within rules of conduct, and monitored for compliance, and run by war ministries in a near post-scarcity society.

Also includes 3 more Ship Control Cards for the game.

(Publisher blurb)

Name: Hot Streak!
Description:
Hot Streak is a roll and move game combined with a variety of different gambling sub games.  Players move on an inner or outer track and land on properties.  Based on the property they land on players can take a lottery ticket, play a casino game such as slots, bet on a horse race, or acquire one of a handful of Keno parlors.  Players compete to gain the most money without going bankrupt.

In terms of actual game play, there is very little decision making other than the amount of particular bets though even this is fixed for some of the games.  Occasionally players have the option of switching between tracks.  All games are determined by random spins, dice rolls, or draws.  For example, the horse race has six horses starting at the same point and all players bet on a horse; a die is rolled and the corresponding horse advances one space; this continues until one horse has advanced to the finish.  As another example, lottery tickets are simply distributed as one lands on the spot with a random winner drawn later in the game.

The game board is a thin cardboard, the chips and horses are generic plastic pieces.  Generally the quality is below average even for a mass market game.



From the Box --Made by the makers of Nick the Greek Official Casino Gambling Games

The most exciting strategy board game about casino gambling ever made!

Contains: Beautiful casino board game, authentic roulette layout, dice, poker chips, keno parlor ownership cards, roulette/slot machine spinner, six molded race horses, six game tokens, lottery tickets, odds cards, cashier checks, NICK THE GREEK money, plus complete easy-to-follow instructions.

Great fun for the whole family
For 2 to 6 players

All the glitter and fast action of a trip to any one of the world's glamorous gambling casinos.

Get to Play
9 Great Casino Games
Including: Roulette, Blackjack, Poker, Craps, Slot Machine, Horse Race, Chuck-A-Luck, Baccarat, and Keno plus A State Lottery!

Name: Laundry Jumble Game
Description:
It's laundry day and the animals need help getting dressed! Reach inside the dryer to find their
missing clothes and exlpore using only your sense of touch. Think you've found what you're looking
for? Pull it out and see if it's a match! But watch out for the Skunk's Undies or you'll lose a card.
Fun 3-D game play encourages tactile exploration and fine motor skills.

Ages 4 and up.

Honors:
Parent's Magazine Top Toys of 2010 (November 2010 issue, page 164)
Good Housekeeping Magazine Top 6 Games of 2010 (Holiday Issue December 2010)

Designed by Mary Jo Reutter, winner of the 2010 Excellence in Game Design award at the Toy and Game Industry (TAGIE) Awards.

- from the publisher

Name: Disney Princess Friends Forever
Description: Who will be your "PFF" (Princess Friend Forever)? Collect magical Friend Gems as you travel with your Princess BFFs to the enchanted castle.  The first to enter the colorful castle wins the game.  The game is a race using cards and gems for players as princesses to enter the castle.

Name: Flip-a-Longs: Long Long Locomotive
Description:
From the designer

ALL ABOARD! The Long, Long Locomotive is leaving the station and it's full steam ahead for matching fun!

This Flip-A-Longs game is a high-speed adventure where players must have a keen sense of memory as they match scenes to create the longest train on the tracks. Higher level critical thinking is required, imagination is encouraged, and vocabularies are enhanced
in play with Flip-A-Long cards.

Flip-A-Longs cleverly combines puzzle play and memory matching to create an engaging new game that children and adults alike will "FLIP" for! Simply flip over cards, if you find a match, add it to your train to make yours the longest!

Who will be riding on your train? A marching band? A roller  coaster? Spooky ghosts? The player to match the most card and build the longest train wins!

Dynamic game play and silly illustrations encourage memory, matching, counting, dexterity and more! Flip-A-Longs is a game the entire family can play!

Name: Flip-a-Longs: Knights of the Long Table
Description:
From the designer

You have been invited to dine with royalty at the legendary Knights of the Long Table! In this far away land, players must have a keen sense of memory as they match cards to create scenes and build the longest table in the kingdom!

Flip-A-Longs cleverly combines puzzle play and memory matching to create an engaging new game that children and adults alike will "flip" for! Simply flip over cards, if you find a match, add it to your table to make yours the longest!

Who will be seated at your table? Mischievous wizards? Beautiful maidens? Brave knights? The player to match the most cards and build the longest table wins!

Dynamic game play and silly illustrations encourage memory, matching, counting, dexterity and more! Flip-A-Longs is a game the entire family can play!

Name: Garanimals Paw Prints
Description:
This game is part of the Paw Prints Floor Games series.

Paw tiles are placed on the ground, and several games are played as children need to step on the `paw prints' in animal fashion.  In the game "Let's Switch", you need to pick an animal print and act like that animal until you draw a card with a different animal. In the game "Time to Go Home", you need to follow directions to bring the animals home.

As the the inventor, I have found through dozens of classroom studies that children love to carry this game with them everywhere they go. That is why I designed the tote box to make them easier to carry with them.

There are no limits to this game, you can make up any game you like, like :hide and go feet" and countless others.... just let your children come up with their own!

Name: Fish-a-Ree
Description:
Time to fish, but you're rewarded only when you catch the right pair of fish so pay attention to who's swimming where - and stay away from the boot!

To set up Fish-a-Ree, players must first open the game board, then set it on top of the game cannister. Then insert the ten fish tiles and two boot tiles into the dozen slots on the game board.

On a turn, a player reveals one of the 24 number cards, then pulls out two tiles – one at a time – by pulling on the ring at the top of the tile. The player then lays out the tiles against the ruler included in the game. If the sum of the lengths of these fish equal the number card, then the player keeps the card. If not – or if a player draws a boot – then he scores nothing. In either case, the player must return the tiles to the locations where they were originally located.

The first player to collect five cards wins.

Name: Fancy Nancy's Fabulous Fashionista Game
Description:
Designed by Mary Jo Reutter, winner of the 2010 Excellence in Game Design award at the Toy and Game Industry (TAGIE) Awards.

For 2-4 players ages 5 and up, players must try to gather an fashion outfit, and create a glorious ensemble!

In Fancy Nancy Fabulous Fashionista Game,players assemble their Fancy Nancy ensembles (held in the armoire and shoe rack!) by trading and collecting the necessary fashion elements.  The first to have three runway-ready outfits is the winner.

The game comes with 4 armoires and shoe racks; 12 matching dress and shoe tokens and rules for different ways to play.  Also included are bonus cling stickers that can be used to fancy-up the armoires or just about anything else that needs that special touch!

Released early in 2011, and published by BriarPatch.

Name: Buck Buck Moose
Description:
This is a color matching game for younger children, where players have fun in the forest with moose!

Players take turns dealing cards featuring Buck the Forest Ranger and his pokey pal Moose. Get a "Buck" card and do nothing -- get a colored "Moose" card and race the other players to slap the stack of cards with the matching color. Get there first and you win the card! The player with the most cards at the end of the game wins! Fast-action, color-matching forest fun!

Name: Donjons & Trésors
Description:
From the back of the box but translated:
In Donjons et trésors, you and your friends plays each one of the 6 characters : The elf, the barbarian, the mage, the thief, the dwarf and the robber.
You walk with your lantern to seek adventures and fabulous treasures that are in dungeons. But, especially you want to be rich, your ultimate goal is to find gold.
Multiple pitfalls are wainting you in your periple, fierce creatures will attack you and sneaky traps will block you. 
To help you, you can have with allies, issue some prisoners and discover hidden treasures, You will find also equipment that permits you to overcome all dangers that you will encounter.

Theme : exploring dungeons, kill monsters and seek gold.
Game-play : play cards to gain gold for your character and lose gold for the others.
Goal:

From the back of the box:
"Dans Donjons et trésors, vous et et vos amis incarnez un des 6 personnages disponibles : l'Elfe, le Barbare, le Magicien, le Voleur, le Nain et le Pilleur.
Vous avancez à l'aide de votre lanterne à la recherche d'aventures et de fabuleux trésors que les donjons renferment. Mais surtout, vous voulez être riche, votre but ultime c'est de trouver de l'or.
De multiples embûches vous attendent dans votre périple, des créatures féroces vous attaqueront et des pièges sournois bloqueront votre progression.
Pour vous aider, vous pourrez être accompagné par des alliés, délivrer les prisonniers et découvrir des trésors cachés. Vous trouverez aussi de l'équipement vous permettant de surmonter tous les dangers que vous rencontrerez.

Name: Bowling Zombies
Description:
Publisher Blurb:

There are some trouble-makers in town. They're hungry, they're rotting, and they're just plain dead! Can you bowl the helpless damsel to freedom without being eaten? This fun table-top bowling game is designed for take-anywhere play, while at home, work or digging up old friends. Whether you're a zombie hunter or a helpless damsel yourself, you are sure to have an exciting time knocking down zombies while avoiding a lethal knock to the blonde-haired damsel herself.

Features hand-painted wooden pins and bowling ball and is packaged in a travel friendly tube.

Name: Kampf der Saurier
Description:
Fighting Dinosaurs

Two Triceratops meet in a narrow canyon.
Neither of them will give in and so they start a fight. Every rock is essential now. Who is the strongest one in the end? A game of dice for two players that train your skills.

Players throw the dice. This is the number of spaces you are allowed to push your dinosaur forward. The aim is to push the Triceratops of your opponent off the plank.
On the plank there are also rocks between the dinosaurs. If a rock falls of the plank your turn ends and you are not allowed to finish your move.

Components:
2 dinosaurs
20 rocks
1 plank
1 dice with a sticker sheet.

This game is part of the T-ReX World line of die Spiegelburg.

Name: Famous Last Lines
Description: "In Famous Last Lines, by actresses Daryl Hannah and Hilary Shepard, players read the movie title and plot and create their own “fake” last line of the movie. Movie categories include Drama, Comedy/Romance, Action/Western, Sci-Fi/Horror/Mystery, Family/Animation, and Classics/Musical. The object of the game is to bluff other players into guessing that your last line is the most believable one. Players earn points by fooling others or by correctly guessing the true last line…so lights, camera, ACTION!"

Name: Great War at Sea: Confederate States Navy
Description:
A DIY expansion for the Great War at Sea series that assumes the Civil War had turned out differently.

From the APL website... "When Confederate Gen. Albert Sidney Johnston’s Army of Mississippi destroyed the Union’s Army of the Tennessee at Shiloh in April 1862, it brought despair to a Northern public already restive over the war’s course. A few weeks later the entire world saw how a single Confederate ironclad could isolate the Union’s Army of the Potomac on the Virginia Peninsula; the Union ship that might have saved the day, the ironclad Monitor, had been swamped in heavy seas and sank before it could arrive on the scene. With no help of reinforcement, resupply or rescue and Robert E. Lee’s Army of Northern Virginia launching incessant attacks, George McClellan surrendered his command. The American Civil War was over after roughly a year of fighting.

Fifty years later, the United States and Confederate States share a divided continent. The South has expanded into the Caribbean Basin and Central America, cutting a canal across Nicaragua and establishing new states and territories. Under pressure from their British and French allies, the Confederate States gradually eliminated slavery, but severe class and racial tensions remain. Northern politicians know talk of re-unification is an easy crowd-pleaser; even the United States Navy continues to name warships for Southern states and cities.

War in Europe has finally brought the long-simmering American feud into open conflict. The United States, pressured by its German allies, seeks to disrupt trade through the Caribbean Basin and deny these resources to the Allied war effort. The Confederacy, outnumbered and outgunned by its rival, must protect its economic lifelines if it is to survive as an independent state.

Confederate States Navy is a supplement for the Great War at Sea series, based on battles that never happened, waged by a fleet that never existed. It is not a complete game: Ownership of U.S. Navy Plan Gold is necessary to play most of the 10 scenarios included and Jutland, Pacific Crossroads, Mediterranean, Sea of Troubles and Black Waters to play all of them.

Confederate States Navy is sold exclusively via .pdf download. The playing pieces are not die-cut and mounted, nor is the scenario book printed. Instead it comes as a series of .pdf files that will need to be assembled into the game’s components."
Families: Series: Great War at Sea (Avalanche Press)

Name: Ethereum
Description:
Shores of Heaven(TM) Ethereum is a new game with the same characters introduced in Shores of Heaven. Through played missions, the stories of this universe unfold.

Akzinal - Brilliant thieves on a race against time to rescue a world from implosion.
Felian - A brutal race hell-bent to control the galaxy.
Homin - An evil force has destroyed the home world of Erychosia. Can they find the key to time travel and stop the disaster before it happens?
Morph - Shape-shifting people seeking to develop their civilization through technology.
Ralyk - Fighting "the madness", a terminal disease, the Ralyk try to improve their genetic codes and overcome the disease by stealing genes from other species.
Varpor - Fed up with the wars, kidnappings, thieveries and utter violence that has overtaken the galaxy, the Varpor, and their liveship Sunrays take it upon themselves to police the galaxy and restore order.
Wallaboo also make an appearance in the form of a powerful ally.

Aside from missions, Ethereum adds worlds into play. Trading is introduced as a playing mechanic, and civilizations develop by developing technologies that will help each to fulfill their story. Each world has a unique power, and when the powers collide, the battles are certain to be epic.

This is, at this time, a print and play game. The rule set, all cards and sheets are provided on this site for your printing and reference.Again, the rules are quite simple, and play should begin perhaps less than 10 minutes after resources have been printed. Though cubes can be purchased for easier game play, scratch paper works as well.

This is NOT an expansion. This is a completely new game with the same incredible characters. This might be compared to a much easier way of learning a thematic game like Twilight Imperium or Galactic Emperor. And thank you Christian Peterson and Adam West for your incredible contributions toward playing mechanics and story-based game play.

Name: Foresight
Description:
(from publisher's website)

Foresight is a unique deck of cards, unlike any other deck you’ve ever used.  The cards are familiar, as long as you’re looking at the fronts, lovingly illustrated by Aaron Williams. But on the back, one or more suits appear, giving you a glimpse into the future.  The better the card, the less information you have about what suit it is.  That ability to look into the future gives the game its shape, and presents some unique challenges for the veteran card player.

Foresight is also an engaging trick-taking card game, using that special set of cards.  The bidding system is at once familiar, a simple system of bidding how many tricks you are going to take, and different, in that you get to bid multiple times.  As befits a game with as much uncertainty as Foresight features, you get to place several bets, rather than be locked down into one bid.  And once play begins, part of your hand is obscured even from you.  Managing your information and your crucial hole cards is a skill that is unique to playing Foresight, and it’s a fresh challenge that card players everywhere can appreciate.

Name: Avodome
Description: A fun family game for 2 to 6 players.  "An adrenaline pumping race to avoid the dome and reach home."  Players take turns hopping around the board, collecting boosters, blocking their opponents and trying to win the game by transferring all of their pieces to the finish area.  Game duration - between 30 and 60 minutes.

Name: Potion magique
Description: There are three potion ingredients (toad, flower, leaf), each of which comes in three colors (red, purple green). Players take turns to be Merlin and ask the other player to find out what's in a potion. The other player plays ingredient cards and Merlin has to tell how many ingredients were correct (Mastermind-style). The goal is to find out the exact recipe for three potions in as few attempts as possible.

Name: BasketBoard
Description:
Basketball dunked in a box! All the excitement and the fast-thrilling actions of a basketball match recreated in a family game.

By rolling two special dices, the players can organize their attack actions, by passing, running or shooting, while the opponents will try to stop them by defending their area. Are you able to score before the time in the shoot clock ends?

The first team who scores 25 points during the 4 periods of the match wins the game! And with the special “team rules”, the game goes up to 10 players!

Name: Objection! Justice Duel
Description:
Game description from the publisher:

In Objection! Justice Duel, each player plays the role of a lawyer who tries desperately, trial after trial, to acquire more and more fame. In each trial, the players try to overcome the opponent by getting the most valuable combination of cards, using the points at their disposal to fish or to reveal new cards to bluff or to block the opponent's shouting of "Objection!"

Who will be the most famous lawyer at the end of the game?

Name: Decisive battle! A Baoa Qu
Description:
This is web-published tactical level space combat wargame based on "Mobile Suit Gundam", is a famous Japanese robotec animation. This game represent final battle between Earth Federation and Zeon Dukedom at Space Fortress A Baoa Qu in TV series episode 42 and 43.

Player control Space Fleet of either Earth Federation or Zeon Dukedom. Each units represent 4 space warships or about 10 to 15 mobile suits.

Turn order decide by chit-pull system. Each force has two activation chits and there are two non-activation chits, but each turn pulled only four chits. So activation order is very randomly. Combat resolve is used fire power CRT and two six side dice.

A victor is decided by the destruction of fortress units and capital ship units.



Official Homepage (Japanese text only)
http://mk2kpfb.html.tv/index.php?%E6%BF%80%E9%97%98%E3%82%A2%E3%83%90%E3%82%AA%E3%82%A2%E3%82%AF%E3%83%BC%E3%81%AE%E9%83%A8%E5%B1%8B

Name: Scorpio
Description: A Trivia game: People answering trivia and move forward toward the goal. The main difference between this and a standard quiz game is that there is a timer and the players have a combined total time to answer all questions

Name: Culture Pop
Description:
From the publisher:

CULTURE POP, the culture-spoofing game of crazy phrases and fill-in-the blank fun!

Make your friends and family laugh by re-shaping phrases from our culture (advertisements, songs, movies, and more) in new and clever ways, according to a given style.  Each turn, one point is awarded to the player who can identify the missing part of the phrase, and one point is awarded to the player who created the best phrase in the new style.  So there are two fun ways to win!

Name: Merkator: Messe Sonderkarte
Description:
Lookout Games offers this special card at the SPIEL10 in Essen.

This card is inside the Lookout Games 10 years anniversary catalog.

The new card has the following abilities:

Card cost: 4 gold 
Victory points: 5
Condition to fulfill: At least one 10 bonus contract

Name: Terra Ventura
Description:
A great explorer, you want to discover unknown, mysterious lands! Speed and observation skills will help you to reach new natural habitats and glimpse the extraordinary cultural diversity of the peoples of the Earth.
Game Objective: Study the card closely and be the first to find the coordinates of the next place you’re looking for. The “action” dice will guide you to get to the spot, but sometimes it’s a bit ... acrobatic! If you are curious and open-minded, the wonders of the planet will be yours, and the locals will welcome you and you win the round!

Name: Un pour Tous
Description:
From the designer:

CONTEXT:
Paris, 1626.
The king´s musketeers, who are carrying a very important message, arrive hasty to Palais Royal.
Hooded silhouettes appear in their way.
Are they Cardinal´s guards, Milady de Winter´s minions or swordsmen ?

The message has to arrive save.
Are they going to face each other, protect each other, stab each other, demonstrate their nobility, or their baseness in order to get this message.

Wear your plume and Fight for your faction !

MECHANIC:
You have to assign your dice between your hands. Players are going to simultaneously make a "posture", using their arms to threat a player or protect themselves, and revealing dice in each hand.

Combats are resolved with simple dice rolls using a "press-your-luck" system with different options (secret moves, counter-attacks, protection of an ally, event cards...).

One pair makes for a hit (touche), that can be parried.

A combination of 3 dice becomes a "secret move", unique and unstoppable for each character.

A "plume" die allows to control luck and take advantage over your opponents.

Name: Tilting Dice
Description:
Tilting dice
by James Ryan

Tilting dice is a two-player abstract strategy game designed for use with Nestortiles. Players construct a modular board and then strategically position their dice to make a capture. When two dice connect, the die with the highest facing side wins.

SET UP:

1) The board:
Each player picks two colors of Nestortiles and takes all the tiles of those colors. The rest of the tiles are shuffled face down and patched together into a 6x6 grid. The grid is flipped over, revealing the pattern of pips. This will be used as the game board.

2) The dice:
Players now use their twelve Nestortiles to assemble two dice in any way they please.

3) Placing the dice on the board:
Players now place their dice in the corners of their own side of the game board with any side face up, so long as it does not match the number of the tile the die is on. Who ever is start player should place his or her dice first, giving the second player a chance to evaluate the position and place his or her dice accordingly.

Example: In one of Eva's corners, there is a tile with four pips. She may place either of her dice in this corner, so long as it is not showing 4 pips on its top face. Once she places both of her dice, it will be Nestor's turn to place his. Then Eva will make the first move.

Players may decide turn order in any manner they like. Start player will alternate each round.

OBJECTIVE:
The first player to "capture" one of the other player's dice wins the round. First player to win 3 rounds wins the game.

GAMEPLAY

1) Moving dice:
When players take their turns, they move one of their dice three times. Moving a die means "tilting" it on to the next space forward, backward, left, or right, so that the top face of the die becomes the side facing that direction.

Example: Eva will play first. She decides to move her die that shows a green 5 on top. First, she will move it one space forward. Eva now tilts the die forward so that the green 5 faces forward and the die rests squarely on the next tile forward.

Now this same die shows a blue 2 on top and she wants to move this one space to the left. She tilts the die to the left so that the blue 2 is now the side facing left and the die lands squarely on the next tile to the left..

Now this die has a blue 5 on top, and Eva wants to move it one more space forward, so she tilts the die forward, moving the die onto the next tile forward so that his blue 5 faces forward, toward her opponent. Eva's turn is turn is now over.

At no point during a player's turn may they move their die back onto a tile it has already touched during the same turn. This means players cannot retrace their path or repeat moves during the same turn.

Dice may not be moved diagonally. Dice may not be rotated.

2) Making a capture:
When two opposing dice are in adjacent squares, their facing sides are compared. The die with the highest value on its facing side captures the other and the round is over.

Example: One of Nestor's dice shows a 4 on one side. Eva is able to move her die so that it ends on the space adjacent to this side with a value of 5 facing Nestor's 4. Eva's 5 beats Nestor's 4, so Eva wins the round.

Dice cannot be captured "in passing." In other words, the sides of dice are not compared for a capture unless a player has completed all three moves of his or her turn. If dice are in adjacent squares on the first or second move of a turn, there is no comparison of sides and no capture.

Sometimes, a die will end a turn on a "matching" tile. A die is said to be on a matching tile when its top face is of the same value as the tile. When a die is on a matching tile, all of its outward facing sides double in value for as long as the die remains on the matching tile. This means it may capture a die showing a side of greater value than it would normally be able to capture.

Example: One of Eva's dice is on a matching space, and its outward facing sides show values of 2, 3, 4, and 4. Because she is on a matching tile, their values are now 4, 6, 8, and 8. As soon as she moves off the tile, their values will return to normal.

Let's say Eva ended her turn on a matching tile that is adjacent to one of Nestor's dice. His die shows a 6 facing hers, and her die shows a 4 facing his. Ordinarily Eva would lose the round in this position, but because she is on a matching tile, the value of her 4 doubles to an 8. Her 8 beats Nestor's 6 and she wins the round.

If dice are compared for capture and their values are equal, no capture takes place on that turn.

STARTING A NEW ROUND

Once a capture has been made, players collect their dice and prepare for a new round. Players should decide before a game begins whether or not they want the ability to remake their dice between rounds. Unless otherwise stated, dice should retain their composition for the duration of the game, and the board should likewise remain intact for all 3-5 rounds.

The game ends when a player has won three rounds and is declared the winner.

Name: Higher or Lower
Description:
Q: What is the average weight of an adult male blue whale (to the nearest tonne)?

How many people would know the answer to this question... not many you may say!  But there's always some 'smarty pants' with a photographic memory for this type of information.

And how many games have you played where the person in the lead just moves further ahead... and wins.  There's no excitement in that!  "Higher-or-Lower" is different.  It allows anyone to play... 'smarty pants' or not... and everyone has an equal chance of getting the answer right... even if you don't have the faintest idea of what it is!

"Higher-or-Lower" combines the fun of learning, with a playing board where players can be blocked from moving.  "Chance" questions can boost you higher... while those annoying "Group" questions can see you slide lower.

Add to this the delight of the last person (to depart the bottom row) collecting and placing those 'land mine' like yellow "Group" disc's anywhere on the board at anytime, and "Higher-or-Lower" offers a riot of fun and entertainment to all!

(from the back of the box)

Name: The Rivals for Catan: Axel the Innovator
Description:
This 2010 promo card for The Rivals for Catan was given out by Klaus Teuber at SPIEL10 in Essen (and can also be bought in the Catan Shop).

Ability of the card:

Reißen Sie ein Gebäude ab. Ersetzen Sie es durch ein anderes Gebäude und zahlen Sie soviel Gold, wie das neue Gebäude mehr kostet als das abgerissene. Baubedingung beachten!

Remove a building. Replace it with another building and pay the difference of the building costs in gold. Observe the building rules!

Name: Biatlon
Description:
From the back of the game box

Who will be the hero of snowy slopes? Who will hit the most targets and reach the finish line first? Will it be a Bear, a Wolf or a Fox?

Biathlon is a fast-paced, educative and extremely fun board game which will keep all family members occupied. A perfect game for long winter evenings!

Compete with other players in cross-country skiing; your speed increases with every successfully memorized card and there are other equally interesting disciplines such as howling and hooting which will make you laugh!

You will love Biathlon because it motivates you to act and think fast; Rules can be adapted for all age groups; This game encourages children to improve their visual memory; Biathlon guarantees hours of fun for all family members.

Name: Gummy Bear Factory
Description:
Gummy Bear Factory is a card game designed by BGG user ralpher and his wife, Saya Tsong.  Gummy Bear Factory is a Euro-style filler card game with elements inspired by great card games such as Bohnanza, Lost Cities, and Great Wall of China.

Description from TheGamecrafter.com:

Life as a worker in a Gummy Bear Factory is tough!  Not only do you have to make each gummy bear by hand, you have to watch out that your sneaky coworkers don't try to build off your labors and take credit for your work!

Gummy Bear Factory is a fast-paced card game of trading and set collection for 1-5 players, playable from ages 8 and up.

The game uses unique cards composed of heads, middles or legs gummy bears in different colors.  On your turn, you take or trade for gummy bear parts and try to lay down complete gummy bears of three matching cards.  Players build new gummy bears or onto existing gummy bears.  The game is won by the player who created the most gummy bears and scores the most bonus points for having majority control on a row.  The game is easy to learn, but it takes strategy and cunning to win.

The game is inspired from European boardgame design.  It emphasizes easy to teach rules, no player elimination, no language, and game mechanics that emphasize strategy and paying attention to the gameplay rather than completely luck.

Gummy Bear Factory is the only game that you can use real gummy bears in place of the included scoring winks and increase your fun!  You provide your own.  Symbols allow easy play for color blind players.  There's also a challenging solitaire variant and special two player rules.

Name: Unistuste Agentuur
Description:
From the rules:

Game is based on a TV show here in Estonia called "Unistuste Agnetuur" ("Dream Agency").
In it a story telling game in which each player must make a dream party for the customer.
In each turn one player is a customer and all other players are dream party makers.
Before customer takes a card from a theme deck, each player takes 1 card from 4 card piles (not the theme deck). On each of those card are 1 word. Now, the customer says the theme and each player now must put together a party idea for the customer using those 4 cards in their hand.
After which, customer will decide who had the best idea and went close to what he / she wanted.
Game goes on until everyone has been a customer.

You win the game if you have collected the most theme cards while making the best parties. If two or more players have equal number of cards, then they must count flowers on them. Each flower is a point and a level of difficulty (1-easy, 3 hard).

Name: Ärihai
Description:
The goal is to rise your firms stock times 20 it was at the beginning of the game. The whole game is a cross-breed from Monopoly and Cashflow.

Each player gets one firm at the beginning of the game and starts to develop it step-by-step by moving from the developers track to the wall street track and from there to the win.

During the game you do a lot of selling and buying, going through business schools and paying fines to other companies.

You win the game when you have raised the stock value 20 times.

--description from publisher

Name: Card Wars
Description:
Played with a standard deck of playing cards.

2-player rules:
One player takes all the red cards; the other black cards. 
Jokers or the card box are laid to form the central tile of a 5x5 grid. Players each lay a card orthogonally adjacent to this central tile.

Then players take turns either:
  - laying any card in an empty space orthogonally adjacent to an existing friendly card.
  - laying any card on top of a friendly card (to increase defence).
  - laying a card on top of an enemy card. This can only be done if the enemy card is orthogonally adjacent to a friendly card AND the card being laid is higher in rank than the existing card.
  
The winner is the one to occupy more spaces.

3 player game:
Players 1 and 2 take a suit each. Player 3 takes 2 suits, giving them stronger card to make up for being wedged in the middle.

4 player game:
Each player uses one suit.

Name: Doppel-Grübel
Description:
This game is very similar to Memory, but it is an educational game. The pairs consist of a tile with a picture and a tile with the matching word. Whether a picture and a word belong together can be checked by a code at the side of the tiles. As in Memory, the players try collect tile pairs until the playing area is cleared; the player with the highest stack at the end of the game is the winner.

Several editions have been announced by the publisher; as of Essen 2010, only the one about musical instruments seems to be available.

Name: Down in Flames: Guns Blazing – Extra Decks
Description:
Publisher Blurb:

The card decks contained in the Down In Flames - Guns Blazing game will accommodate up to 6 players. However, if you want to play monster air battles, this is the item for you!

This is functionally an expansion as it ups the number of players in the game from six to twelve.

Name: Ko Shogi
Description: KÅ shÅgi is a large-board variant of shogi, or Japanese chess. The game dates back to the turn of the 18th century and is based on xiangqi and go as well as shogi. Credit for its invention has been given to Confucian scholar OgyÅ« Sorai. Unlike standard shogi, pieces may not be dropped back into play after being captured. Promotion rules are complex, and the fates of several pieces are interdependent. The objective is to capture the opponent's commanding pieces: The general, plus the governor if present, or either the banner or middle army if not. Two players, Black and White, play on a go board ruled into a grid of 19 ranks (rows) by 19 files (columns) with a total of 361 intersections. Each player has a set of 90 pieces of 34 different types. The pieces are round and flattened like go stones. In all, the players must remember 65 different moves. The pieces are generally of the same size, though black pieces may be slightly larger than white pieces. Each piece has its name in the form of one or two Japanese characters marked on its face, in white on black stones and in black on white stones. On the reverse side of most pieces are other characters in red; this side is turned up to indicate that the piece has been promoted during play. - Wiki (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ko_shogi)

Name: 40 Hats for 40 Cats
Description:
The game consists of 40 cat puzzle pieces and 40 hat puzzle pieces.  Players draw 4 cats and race to find their 4 matching hats. A round ends when one person completes their 4 pairs.

In subsequent rounds, each player draws a new set of 4 cats and play continues until there aren't enough cats left for everyone to have four.  The player with the most matches wins.

{user summary}

Name: Exclusive Warehouse 23 Munchkin Booster
Description: The Exclusive Warehouse 23 Munchkin Booster is pretty much described by the name: a fixed set of cards for the various Munchkin games sold exclusively through publisher Steve Jackson Games' retail outlet, a.k.a. Warehouse 23. A booster was released annually between 2010 and 2014, and in 2016 Steve Jackson Games re-released all of the standard-sized Munchkin cards from those boosters as Munchkin Hidden Treasures.

Name: Necromancer: Rise of the Undead
Description:
Necromantic acolytes are dueling in a deserted graveyard to become the most powerful Necromancer! This is achieved by collecting arcane tomes of power & the chest of ultimate secrets, or by destroying your enemies minions with devastating spells and hordes of undead monsters.

This game has been taken to several war gaming conventions in the uK where it achieved Best Participation game at Warfare (Reading 2010)

The games consists of 4 players each representing a Necromancer in charge of an undead horde. To begin with eaxh player has 3 ghouls, these are; fast, good at searching but weak in combat. During each turn the players will raise a skeleton and a zombie to supplement their force. So more figures will enter play as the game progresses. The turn order is determined randomly by pulling stones from a bag. There are six stones, one for each player and the other two represent the resurrection of skeleton & zombie. When a players stone is drawn, they are allowed to move all their figures. No diagonal movement is allowed, nor are you allowed to enter a space occupied by other players pieces, and finally there's a stcking limit of 4 figures per area. After moving any figures against to an enemy must fight (this is compulsory), otherwise they may search for artifacts. Specially prepared dice are used for both searching & combat. These dice have the following faces; 2 x swords, 1 x shield, 2 x eye and 1 x swirl. During searching a number of dice are rolled, if any show the 'eye' the item has been found and will need to be carried back to the Necromancer in order to be used or scored. In combat, both players roll their respective dice, lokking for swords or shields. Basically a shield will negate a sword, any any excess swords on either side will kill a minion each. Spells can be played to influence the outcome of a battle ie 'Battle rage' - All swirls count as swords, thereby increasing your chance of killing your opponents figures.

zombies are slow, not good in searching but the best fighters, skeletons are average across the board. The Necromancer himself, is very good at searching, but otherwise similar to a skeleton.Points are awarded for kills and for collecting items. The first player to acquire 25 points wins. Sets of gems are worth more than singles, scrolls give you another spell but are not worth any points, relics are worth 2 points, the chest is 4 (this is placed in the centre of the board) and potions are worth 1 but can be used in combat to roll an extra die. Kills are worth 2 points each, however the Necromancer is immortal so each wound he takes is worth 2.

Name: Iron bottom & Sunset sky
Description:
A cardgame for 2 players which simulates battle of Savo island in 1942-43.  Designed by Tomoki Kondoh.
Each player gets ship cards and aircrafts cards and must get VPs from eliminating enemy forces or getting enemy bases.
Moderate complexity and takes about 60 minutes.

Name: Polish Campaign Pack
Description:
This is a 10 scenario pack for Advanced Squad Leader that covers the Polish Campaign of September and October of 1939.

The scenarios are:

FE 176 Defense of Wysloka - A German Grenadier unit is attempting to bypass a mixed unit of Polish infantry and motorized artillery.

FE 177 First Invasion of Germany - German units are trying to disengage from a Polish armored force advancing toward the German border. This scenario requires board FE1. (Not included in the pack)

FE 178 Crushing Polish Victory - A Polish mixed force must attempt to block a German armored formation from penetrating to the rear.

FE 179 Jakacking Ass - Polish infantry attempting to hold a town against a German armored formation.

FE 180 Andrzejewo Aflame - Polish infantry attempt to avoid a German pincer movement in the middle Polish campaign.

FE 181 Gardens of the Citadel - German and Polish combined forces engage in city combat.

FE 182 Shredkowice - More city combat as a small force of grenadiers encounters a Polish infantry unit bolsters by some tough artillery pieces.

FE 183 Take the Flag - A Polish cavalry unit must evade German infantry in its flight to Warsaw.

FE 184 Hurrah! - Polish cavalry attempt to evict a German infantry force from a Monastery.

FE 185 Assault on Fort IX - Late Polish campaign action as the Germans attempt to breach a flooded anti-tank ditch.

Name: Schlaf gut, kleiner Mondbär
Description:
Schlaf gut, kleiner Mondbär is for the very young and consists of animal figurines and many star tokens. The animals are dealt out, then the players take turns rolling a die. If a player rolls an animal, they can take the animal if it is with another player. If a player rolls a star, they can put as many stars back into the box as the number of animals they currently have.

The first player to get rid of all of their stars is the winner!

Name: Story Time
Description:
Story Time was the Southern California finalist in the 2010 Rio Grande Games Design Contest.

Story Time is a competitive card game with a story writing theme.  Each player chooses a character in the story and tries to guide the story so that his or her character fares the best.  The pages of the story are represented by cards, with each card having both story text and game rules.  The players build the story by taking turns adding pages.  Several times during the game the story is read.  During the reading, the game rules on each page of the story are followed in turn.  Those rules will result in the players gaining or losing points depending on how well their characters fare in the story.  At the end of the game there is one final reading, and the player with the most points wins.

Name: Etsu-To-Ga Sanshushi
Description:
This is self-published expansion kit for the "Sengoku Gunyuden" series.
"Etsu-To-Ga Sanshushi" means Records of Three province, Ecchu, Noto and Kaga.

This game covering battles of Hokuriku region in TenshÅ era (1573-1592 AD).
Six scenarios and one campaign game include in this kit.

Name: CONTACT! The Canadian Army Tactical Training Wargame
Description:
User's summary, partly paraphrased from the introduction:

CONTACT! is a set of tactical wargaming rules developed by the Canadian Army Combat Training Centre as a training aid. It is based on a simplified version of the "Wargames Rules for Armoured Warfare 1950-1985", published by the Wargames Research Group (WRG) in 1979. It is played on a terrain model using miniatures representing single vehicles, infantry sections, and crew-served weapons. Players adopt the roles of commanders of platoon or company sized groups. The game requires at least a neutral player in the role of controller, who sets the scenario, supervises play and resolves disputes. Combat is resolved by percentile dice rolls on probability tables, modified by range, suppression status, movement and terrain.

Editor John Curry added some weapon tables for the British and American Army, and additional information and order of battles for Canadian, Warsaw Pact and British forces.

Name: Terra Shrinka
Description:
Terra Shrinka is a cooperative dam-building survival game for 1-4 players.  Terra Shrinka has a unique lunar tide system that controls the water and will erode the island if you don't work together to scout out the island, gather resources, and build dams fast enough.

THE STORY SO FAR

On a South Pacific flight your plane is struck by lighting and makes an emergency landing on a small desert island.  The good news is that everyone survived the landing, the bad news is that the tides are rising and the island is flooding.  It's up to the brave passengers to step forward and bring order to the chaos.  You survived the crash, now can you survive the flood?  The very earth is shrinking around you!  Can you dam the flood?

THE OBJECTIVE

Dam the flood by creating an unbroken chain of dams from one board edge to the other and protect the crash-site in the process!

HOW THE GAME PLAYS

The game starts with the board taking its turn. The board’s turn is broken into five phases:

1. Move Moon Tracker
2. Add Flood Cube(s)
3. Roll Moon Die that matches current Moon Phase
4. Draw card if “N” or “S” is rolled.
5. Move Flood water and resolve damage

After the water does a good job of destroying board squares, it is the players’ turn. Each player starts with their Team Leader in the Crash Site. During the players’ turn, they do the following:

1. Explore and Move
2. Create
3. Transfer
4. Set Dams

Each player has a starting character. Are you the ren-faire blacksmith, or are you the bag lady? No matter whom, it is each team’s job to explore this uncharted little island. The survivors find food to bribe more recruits off the plane. They make networks of people to transfer gathered goods. And finally, they create and set dams to stop the water. This requires lots of communication and teamwork to protect your Crash Site and stop the water from spreading any more. If your Crash Site is destroyed, you lose. Otherwise, keep track of how many squares were destroyed when you finally blocked off the flood and try to do better next time. There are additional scenarios to add replay value and ensure that you want to come back for more.

Name: Vampire Diaries Card Game
Description:
Try to be the first player to collect the characters in this hit CW TV show. Getting the crow card will let you take a card from another player and having the herbal Vervain card protects your character cards. Other twists and surprises add to the fun.

-Publisher

Starting with a hand of 3 cards, Draw a card from the deck. Then play a card. You can meld a character card or use one of the other cards that have special effects. If you cannot play a card, discard one from your hand.

The first player to have collected all six character cards and the special two-sided Elena/Kathrine card winns.

Name: The Little Big Game of aCowntin
Description:
From the back of the box:

COWntless hours of entertainment with family and friends. Forget cows or balancing the books, this fast-paced card game has everything to do with rolling the dice to be the first to get rid of all your cards.


     Roll the dice!
     Do the math!
     Lay down the cards that qualify!
     First players to lay down all the cards in their hand, wins the game.
     Watch out for the Cow eyes!


Includes: Two decks of 48 cow cards - numbered 1-12 in four colours, dice and instructions.


     * *


Summary:

In this light children's card game, players begin with a hand of cards, each of which is numbered (1-10). On their respective turns, each player rolls a pair of six-sided dice and tries to discard a card from his/her hand based on the result rolled. The numbers on the dice are combined using simple mathematical operations to determine whether a card can be discarded. For example, if a player rolls a 3 and a 2, they could discard a 1 (3-2), a 5 (3+2), or a 6 (3x2). A player who cannot discard must draw an additional card. The first player to empty their hand wins.

Name: Brass Balls & Nerves of Steel
Description:
Manufacturer's Description: 
Which do you have? Do you have the skill? Do you have the will? Roll balls to score 1, 2, or 3 points but watch out! Roll too hard and you'll give a free shot to your opponent - too soft and you might score on yourself! With fun, fast-paced gameplay, Brass Ball & Nerves of Steel is an addictive diversion that everyone will want to play again and again.

This game combines bowling and tic-tac-toe.  One side has 3 brass balls, the other 3 steel balls, and you try to roll your balls into the holes on your opponent's side.  There is a nice combination of risk assessment and dexterity: the farther up the opponent's side you get your ball to go, the more points -- the rows of holes score 1, 2 or 3 points.  If you miss and it rolls back into a hole on your side, it counts for your opponent's score.  And if you roll off the far side, your opponent keeps the ball to roll and score on his own.

Name: Jóla jóla spilið
Description:
Contains two games in one box. From the publisher:
Giftrace: You are Santa Claus and you need to follow the path from the beginning to the end. On your way you leave one gift (a ring in your colour) on each house when you land on a house square or pass it. Score points are given accourding to who is first, second, third and forth to arrive to the end zone. The first person gets 4 points, second gets 3 pts, the third gets 2 pts and the last one gets one point. But, for each gift that you still have remaining (rings on your pawn) you get one minus point for each ring! The person with the most points wins!

Sledrace: Each player chooses a pawn and puts it on the sled in the same colour. The rings are not used in this game. The person that looks most like a racing driver starts! You throw the die and move accordingly. When you land on a square with a picture, you immediately follow the instructions on that square, then your turn ends. Please note that if you pass an X you stop right away because you just hit a tree and the rest of your moves in that turn are cancelled! The player on your left goes next. The first person to reach the finish line wins and gets the trophy!

Name: Home Sweet Home
Description:
3-4 players build their homes from scratch in 14 rounds in HSH. Each player starts with his own mat that represents his home, and hires technicians to develop and decorate it with furniture, appliances, antiques, and shield it against the evil eye of his neighbors -who really can cause major damage!
Every turn consists of 6 phases. In the last phase of every turn, players organize a party to gloat about their new acquisitions.

Name: Dispatches from the Bunker #31
Description:
A magazine dedicated to Advanced Squad Leader. This issue has articles on how to prepare a good setup and perspectives on three scenarios. Also included are four scenarios:

DB082 Roadside Assistance - This scenario set in late war Greece has a German halftrack with mechanical problems waiting for assistance when local partisans attempt to knock it out.

DB083 Block to Bataan - This scenario is set in the Philippines in the early war, features an armored engagement between the Philippine Army supported by US Armor and the Japanese.

DB084 Pot of Stew - The action here is set in Russia during the Kursk offensive of 1943.

DB085 The 138 of the 138th - The Germans are making one last push to take the factory district in Stalingrad. This scenario uses the Red Barricades board.

Name: Blick hinter die Kulissen
Description:
This educational game shows the consequences of lobbying for fair trade relations with third world producers. It is used in schools of the German state of Rheinland-Pfalz, with the goal of inspiring students to put pressure on their communities to buy fair trade goods. 
Up to five players represent importers of third world goods (bananas, stones, coffee, tea and cotton clothes), trying to be the one with the greatest profit who doesn't get caught either overcharging the buyers or inhumanly exploiting the producers. The board has five tracks, one for each product (for the sake of the game, they all have the same price). On the track, there are three markers: The lowest is the price that the producers get; the middle one represents the overall cost including shipping costs, the third one the price that a municipality buys the goods for (the distance between the latter two is the profit margin). The mechanism is a simple "play one card, draw one card". The cards have events printed on them, with each event either influencing the own track (with some choices to make) or that of another player. There are also hidden cards which can be played face-down to another player's track. These are revealed at the end of the game and influence the the maximum prize a municipality will pay and the maximum abuse of producers it will tolerate. A player who exceeds either of these levels is out of the game; the remaining player with the highest profit margin is the winner.
The game has some push your luck element (you can make a rough guess about the tolerable levels from the number of cards played against you) and is embedded in a curricular project in the schools of the state. 
It is not for sale nor does it come in a box. 12 copies were hand-made by Reinhold Wittig, of which 10 copies will be used in schools beginning in 2011.

Name: Take That The Game
Description:
Hi Fans!  How would you like to tour with Take That?

Play the Take That game and be part of our exciting, hectic lives.  We all need personal assistants to take care of us 24 hours a day

You'll get closer to us than anyone and you'll have to be prepared for anything!  From appearing in our videos, to organising our parties and even sharing our secrets.

So everyone take your pick and take us around the world!  Who will it be?  Gary, Howard, Jason, Mark or Robbie.  Choose your favourite and Take Them around the world!

Source: box

Name: Menagerie Mogul
Description:
From the prototype rulebook:

"You have been hired as curator of a brand new zoo in Europe. Your job is to build a world-class collection of animals for the awaiting public. However, your opponents have been hired in similar positions at competing zoos. Be strategic in the use of your resources, and assemble your collection wisely. If you succeed, you will be known the world over as Menagerie Mogul!

Over the course of five rounds, players will draft resource cards from an ever-changing selection. They will then use these resources to compete against one another in hopes of acquiring the most prestigious animals in the world for their zoos. At the end of the five rounds, whoever has achieved the goal of curating the most profitable zoo, wins."

Name: Vrooom
Description:
[From Back of Box and User Summary]

Riding in the car has never been so much fun. Players outwit opponents with custom decks in hopes of becoming the ultimate Vrooomster. Vrooom! The travel card game consists of more than 175 common, uncommon and rare cards. The trip may end but the fun never stops. The journey continues by adding cards to your collection.

The aim is to score the most points before either a certain distance is covered by the transportation you are in (eg 10 miles) or when you reach a destination (eg Grandma's House). Vroom is played by playing out 'object' and 'transmission' cards. Object cards are played when the player sees the object on the card (eg 'Stop sign'). Players score points for playing objects and for collecting sets of like objects (the latter achieved through the play of transmission cards).

Name: Choose Your Clues
Description:
A guessing game of Bible people, places, and things!

You get 20 clues to figure out the biblical person, place, or thing. Ready. Go!

Learn the Bible in a fun, new way with Choose Your Clues. Almost 2,000 clues lead you to discover many Bible facts you never knew existed.

Use as few hints as possible and you're the winner!

Three ways to play. Great for family times and travel, too!

(description source: back of the box)

Name: GridBowl
Description:
GridBowl is a simulation of American Football.
In this game you find : touchdown, field goal, punt, play of scrimmage, etc...

This game is played on a large gameboard (110 cm by 50 cm for big version, or 80cm by 45 cm for smaller version). You can play with 11 "football miniatures" (from Miggle Toy, or kaskey kids for example), or with 11 tokens representing players.

Gridbowl is a game of PROGRAMMATION : each turn, you use a PlayBook card. This PlayBook card gives the type of movement for each specific player.

Your opponent does the same with his own PlayBook card.

Once the Playbook cards are chosen, players from each team act alternatively.
So there is a lot of suspense in GriddBowl.

In this game you must anticipate opponent's moves.

Name: Deepsea Desperation
Description:
(from the game) THE OIL IS RUNNING OUT! The days of easy drilling are long gone and oil companies are searching in ever deeper, riskier and more fragile places just to secure our daily fixx of capitalist cog-grease. The battle is on to protect these areas from the next 'Deepwater Horizon' and with a couple of dice, a few coins and a friend, you can re-enact this struggle. It's Greenpeace vs. the Oil Company, trying to establish marine reserves in the very territory the other player wants to exploit. Through a mix of strategic lobbying, exploration, occupation and reserve creation, one of you will triumph. But beware: too many blowouts and you'll have a deepwater slaughter on your hands. And if all the animals die, you both lose!


You only need some coins and 2 dice to play. Everything else is included in the files. Game play takes place on a grided map of the ocean, containing squares of varying depths of water. One player takes on the role of environmental activists, Greenpeace, while the other, the role of a Big Nasty Oil company. Greenpeace is trying to establish marine reserves in the very places that Big Oil is trying to drill. You see, oil (in the form of coins) is available everywhere, but severely limited in shallow and medium depths. So once the easy oil runs out, the oil company is pushed into deep water. Drilling involves rolling two dice, one after the other. If the second number is larger than the first, this drill results in profit (coins equal to the difference in the two numbers) but if you roll a double, it's a blow out. Blow outs are more damaging in deeper water and any blow out might affect surrounding wildlife (animal counters are distributed randomly for each game). If any one species gets totally wiped out, both players lose.

Each player has 3 strategies to choose from each turn and there is enough variation to ensure that no single outcome is guaranteed (although a lot of animals consistently die).

Name: Jingle Jangle
Description:
Designed for the 2010 Christmas Print and Play Game Design Contest, Jingle Jangle is a domino-like placement game which scores points for arranging tiles into the appropriate patterns.

Jingle Jangle uses a special set of 30 tiles with two bells on them called jangles. The game can be played by two, three or four players and the size of the hand varies with the number of players.
• Two players get 14 jangles each, with two jangles left over.
• Three players get 9 jangles each, with three jangles left over.
• Four players get 7 jangles each, with two jangles left over.
In the case of three left over jangles, one is put away out of the game and not exposed, to leave two jangles in the starter. The starter is the pair of left over jangles. These are turned face up and put side by side to make a square in the middle of the table.

Jangles are placed on the table, vertically or horizontally, played out from the starter square. The idea is to build a “crossword puzzle” grid of repeated color patterns in the rows and columns.

Any set of two or more adjacent jangles ending in a row or column is called a group. The jangles must be played so that the bells in each group form a (repeating) pattern. The possible patterns are:

• a single color repeated, example: red, red, red or
• two colors alternating, example: red, blue, red, blue, red, blue or
• three colors in a repeating cycle, example: red, blue, yellow, red, blue, yellow, red, blue, yellow or
• four colors in a repeating cycle, example: red, blue, yellow, green, red, blue, yellow, green or
• or all five colors in a repeating cycle, example: red, blue, yellow, green, purple, red, blue, yellow, green, purple
As soon as a group has a repeated color in it, or contains all five colors, the pattern for that group is fixed, and future jangles that extend the group must conform to the established pattern. As the layout grows, it is possible for a row or column to contain two or more groups, separated by spaces.

Each jangle must be placed so that it correctly extends two or more groups, but you are not allowed to create a set of four jangles side by side in the layout, touching along their long sides.

If a player thinks he cannot play, he exposes his hand. The other players can then (if they wish) point out any plays he might not have seen. In this case the player must play a tile. If more than one possible play is pointed out, the player has the option of picking the one he likes. If no play is pointed out, then the player scores zero and places no jangle. He is not out of the game, but has to wait for his next turn to see if he can then find a play.

The game ends one of two ways: 1) When one player places all his jangles. The other players who started after him get to place one more jangle, however. 2) When no player can place a jangle.

Scores are counted and added as the jangles are placed. Each bell on a jangle is worth 5 points, The score is the product of the new lengths of all extended groups. If the jangle used to extend the group is a double, then the score is also doubled.

All players lose points for the jangles remaining in their hands when the game is ended. Doubles are -5 points and all other jangles are -25 points.

Name: The Smurf Game Happy-time Picture Matching
Description:
The Smurfs are busy having a wonderful time.  Can you match up all your cards to their happy activities?

Source: box

This is a simple game (recommended for ages 4-8) of matching colours and symbols.  Each player has a hand of five cards which they must match to the corresponding spaces on the game board.

Players spin a spinner to determine what colour card they can play and then attempt to match the symbol on their card to a space on the board.  If they have no card of the appropriate colour they must draw from the deck.

The winner is the first to play all their cards.

Name: Maus voraus!
Description:
A piece of cheese is put into the mouth of a battery-driven mouse. The mouse is then set loose on the floor and dashes through the room. The players represent cats and have to catch the mouse's tail with a small plastic sling. The first player to succeed in that gets the cheese. After nine rounds, the player with most points is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

Similar to Maniac Mouse

Name: Cuboid
Description:
Cuboid is a game of skill for two players, to be played with a set of NestorTiles.  The colours of the tiles are significant, but the numbers are ignored.

Each player builds a creature (the Oid) by assembling 6 differently coloured tiles to make a cube.

The remaining 48 tiles are shuffled, and put together randomly to make a 7x7 board, with one gap in the centre.

Starting with the second player, each player puts their opponent's Oid on the board, in an orientation of their choice.

The game begins.  In each turn, players perform the following actions, in order, for each Oid they have on the board:

Eating: if the colour on top of the Oid matches the colour of their tile, the Oid eats that tile.
 Movement: the Oid moves in any orthogonal direction, by (a) sliding over any number of adjacent empty spaces, then (b) rolling onto the first tile it encounters. Oids cannot move onto or past other Oids.

Breeding: if the player's Oids have eaten six tiles, they breed.  Assemble a new Oid, and have the opponent place it on the board next to an adjacent Oid.

The game ends when no more moves are possible.  The player with the most tiles, either as parts or in Oids, is the winner.

Cuboid is an entry in the 1st Nestortiles competition, here:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/580556/1st-nestortiles-game-design-contest-by-nestorgames

Source: author

Name: Spielezeit mit Adelheid
Description: Simple roll-and-move with three pawns each. You have to go through a maze and need cards to pass some spots. There are also spots to draw new cards. Two pawns on the same spot block the space. First player having all three pawns in the goal wins (goal has not to be reached exactely)

Name: Weg mit dir!
